1120727720525099008.text: I know Bitcoin fanatics will say that it is unfair to focus on the illegal transactions using Bitcoin because the dollar is still the currency of choice for most criminals around the world.

1120727715357659136.text: There are some very conflicting messages on where Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies are headed after the bust of last year. I tried to dig beneath the gyrating price to look at how people are actually using the technology today. (a thread of context)https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/23/technology/bitcoin-tulip-mania-internet.html …

1120727718864150528.text: The biggest problem I see is that, aside from speculation, legal, and socially-useful applications of crypto have continually struggled to overtake the illegal and unethical uses of the technology (drugs, ransom, gambling, illegal fundraising).

1120739590619328512.text: There are lots of people working on cool, socially-useful applications for cryptocurrencies. Some of them work in a technical sense today. The problem is that none of them seem to work better enough than existing alternatives to have a broad appeal for ordinary people.

1120727716188155904.text: There are some promising shoots of growth for crypto — in repressive countries and online gaming -- and I was reminded of how much we still don’t know about how cryptocurrencies are used.

1120740297699291136.text: As a point of comparison, in recent days, all the traffic on the 2000 or so Dapps tracked by @Dappradar only amounted to 1/20th of the transaction volume on the Bitcoin blockchain, which is itself less than half of what PayPal managed.

1121555243563491333.text: We wrote about the concerns swirling around Bitfinex, which was then the largest Bitcoin exchange, and its in-house currency, Tether, back in '17 and '18. Today the NYAG said Bitfinex and Tether lost $850m and tried to cover it up.https://ag.ny.gov/press-release/attorney-general-james-announces-court-order-against-crypto-currency-company-under …

1120728777548419074.text: A big question for me is whether the advantages that Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies offers for socially-useful application can manage to outstrip the advantages it offers to socially-dubious applications.

1121868559330598912.text: In the wake of TD Ameritrade quietly opening Bitcoin trading for some of its customers, I was just told that eTrade is preparing to begin offering both Bitcoin and Ether trading to its 5 million or so customers and is just finalizing a third party to actually hold the coins.

1120727719623319553.text: I often hear that the early internet was fueled by illegal activity, but nothing I’ve seen suggests that the illegal activity on the early web reached the scale — or scariness -- of illegal activity with Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies.

1120727717081522176.text: But there are things to worry about. While online payments using Bitcoin declined last year, Bitcoin purchases on the dark net grew steadily, according to data pulled together for us by Chainalysis. Transactions related to theft and hacking grew even faster.pic.twitter.com/jaqtUJYz2w

1007317025939546112.text: The SEC comments this morning seem to have been worded to strongly suggest, without saying it outright, that Ripple's cryptocurrency, XRP should be categorized as a security. Do lawyers out there disagree? And why not just come out and answer this lingering question?

1007302913847263232.text: But Hinman, the SEC official, said that if a token is guided by a third party that holds lots of token, and takes actions to increase the value of that token, it is probably a security. That sounds a lot like a description of Ripple and XRP.

1007301810170654720.text: One big uncertainty hanging over the crypto markets has been whether the 2nd and 3rd largest coins -- Ether and XRP -- should be categorized as securities. A top SEC official just said they don't think Ether should be, but didn't mention XRP.

1007300450884861952.text: “When we look at how Ether today is operating we see a highly decentralized network, and we don’t see a central third party," Hinman said.

1007300030363922432.text: Hinman, the SEC official, said that the key in determining whether a digital asset is a security is the role that a third party plays in the asset. Do they play a key role in the maintenance of the asset? Do they retain a stake in the digital asset?
